title: Michigan State University academics
text:
Michigan State University offers over 200 academic programs at its <a href="East%20Lansing%2C%20Michigan">East Lansing</a>, <a href="Michigan">Michigan</a> campus. MSU is well known for its academic programs in <a href="education">education</a> and <a href="agriculture">agriculture</a>, and the university pioneered the studies of <a href="packaging">packaging</a>, <a href="horticulture">horticulture</a> and <a href="music%20therapy">music therapy</a>. MSU has one of the premier <a href="The%20School%20of%20Hospitality%20Business">hospitality schools</a> in the United States, and the <a href="study%20abroad">study abroad</a> program is the largest of any single-campus university in the nation, offering more than 300 programs in more than 60 countries on all continents, including <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
As a <a href="research%20university">research university</a>, MSU is one of 60 members of the <a href="Association%20of%20American%20Universities">Association of American Universities</a>. Since its inception as a small agricultural college in 1855, MSU has put a strong emphasis on research. Important discoveries made at MSU include hybrid <a href="maize">corn</a>, <a href="Homogenization%20%28chemistry%29">homogenized</a> milk, anti-cancer drug <a href="cisplatin">cisplatin</a>, and <a href="Germanium">Germanium</a> isotope Ge-60. Like other large American universities, MSU has many <a href="teaching%20assistant">teaching assistant</a>s teaching upper-level courses. Michigan State University <a href="Ombudsman">Ombudsman</a> is the oldest continually operating ombudsman office at a college or university in the country.
Organization.
Michigan State University is organized into 17 degree granting colleges
Demographics.
Michigan State has the <a href="List%20of%20largest%20US%20universities%20by%20enrollment">seventh largest</a> student body in the U.S. There are 45,166 total students, with 35,678 <a href="undergraduate">undergraduate</a>s and 9,488 <a href="graduate%20school">graduate and professional</a> students. The student body is 54% female and 46% male. While 89% of students come from all 83 counties in the State of Michigan, also represented are all 50 states in the U.S. and about 125 other countries. MSU has about 4,500 faculty and 6,000 staff members, and a student/faculty ratio of 19:1. Like other large American universities, MSU has a large number of <a href="teaching%20assistant">teaching assistant</a>s teaching upper-level courses. This led "<a href="The%20Princeton%20Review">The Princeton Review</a>" in 2005 to rank MSU eleventh worst in the category of "teaching assistants teach too many upper-level courses".
Rankings.
Michigan State ranks 75th in the world, according to a <a href="Shanghai%20Jiao%20Tong%20University">Shanghai Jiao Tong University</a> study, with "<a href="U.S.%20News%20%26amp%3B%20World%20Report">U.S. News & World Report</a>"'s ranking MSU 82nd in the U.S. The university has over 200 academic programs, several of them highly ranked. "U.S. News" has ranked MSU's graduate-level <a href="elementary%20education">elementary education</a>", <a href="secondary%20education">secondary education</a>, and <a href="Industrial%20and%20Organizational%20Psychology">Industrial and Organizational Psychology</a> programs number one for the last decade. In "U.S. News" also ranks MSU's <a href="nuclear%20physics">nuclear physics</a> program number one. Indeed, MSU's Physics & Astronomy department ranks highly based on the number and impact of publications its faculty publishes. In addition to this, the 2007 U.S. News ranks Michigan State's Supply Chain Management program in the Eli Broad College of Business number one in the nation, beating out MIT (ranked second). The <a href="National%20Communication%20Association">National Communication Association</a> ranks MSU doctoral programs as the nation's most effective in educating researchers in health communication and communication technology. MSU also is ranked in the top four in several other communication fields, including international/intercultural communication, mass communication and interpersonal communication. Other programs of note include <a href="criminal%20justice">criminal justice</a>, <a href="music%20therapy">music therapy</a>, <a href="Hospitality%20industry">hospitality business</a>, <a href="packaging">packaging</a>, <a href="political%20science">political science</a>, and <a href="communication">communication</a>s. MSU's <a href="study%20abroad">study abroad</a> program is the largest of any single-campus university in the United States with 2,461 students studying abroad in 2004–05 in over 60 countries on all continents, including <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a>.
Research.
The university spent nearly <a href="United%20States%20dollar">$</a>380,000,000 million in 2005–06 on research, capping a long history of productive research. In 1877, botany professor <a href="William%20J.%20Beal">William J. Beal</a> performed the first documented genetic crosses to produce hybrid <a href="maize">corn</a>, which led to increased yields. MSU dairy professor <a href="G.%20Malcolm%20Trout">G. Malcolm Trout</a> invented the process for the <a href="Homogenization%20%28chemistry%29">homogenization</a> of milk in the 1930s. In the 1960s, MSU scientists developed <a href="cisplatin">cisplatin</a>, a leading cancer fighting drug. Today Michigan State continues its research with facilities such as the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20Energy">U.S. Department of Energy</a>-sponsored MSU-DOE Plant Research Laboratory and a <a href="particle%20accelerator">particle accelerator</a> called the <a href="National%20Superconducting%20Cyclotron%20Laboratory">National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory</a>. In 2004, scientists at the Cyclotron produced and observed a new isotope of the element <a href="germanium">germanium</a>, called Ge-60. In that same year, Michigan State, in consortium with the <a href="University%20of%20North%20Carolina%20at%20Chapel%20Hill">University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill</a> and the government of <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>, broke ground on the 4.1-meter <a href="SOAR%20Telescope">Southern Astrophysical Research Telescope</a> (SOAR) in the <a href="Andes%20Mountains">Andes Mountains</a> of <a href="Chile">Chile</a>. The consortium telescope will allow the Physics & Astronomy department to study galaxy formation and origins. Since 1999, MSU has been part of another consortium called the <a href="Michigan%20Life%20Sciences%20Corridor">Michigan Life Sciences Corridor</a>, which aims to develop <a href="biotechnology">biotechnology</a> research in the State of Michigan. The College of Communication Arts and Sciences' <a href="Quello%20Center%20for%20Telecommunication%20Management%20and%20Law">Quello Center</a> researches current issues of information and communication management. <a href="Avida">Avida</a>, an artificial life software platform to study the evolutionary biology of self-replicating and evolving computer programs, is under active development by <a href="Charles%20Ofria">Charles Ofria</a> in the Digital Evolution Lab of the Department of Computer Science and Engineering.
<a href="Albert%20Fert">Albert Fert</a> an <a href="Professor%23Other%20designations">Adjunct professor</a> at MSU was awarded the 2007 <a href="Nobel%20Prize%20in%20Physics">Nobel Prize in Physics</a> together with <a href="Peter%20Gr%C3%BCnberg">Peter Grünberg</a>. In February 2010, a $25 million grant was awarded by the <a href="National%20Science%20Foundation">National Science Foundation</a> to the university to develop a Bio/computational Evolution in Action Consortium (BEACON) within the BioMedical and Physical Sciences Building.
Endowment.
MSU's (private, non-Morrill Act) <a href="financial%20endowment">endowment</a> started in 1916 when the Engineering Building burned down. Automobile magnate <a href="Ransom%20E.%20Olds">R. E. Olds</a> helped the program stay afloat with a gift of $100,000. While this opened the door for other types of private donations, MSU has often lagged behind peer institutions in terms of endowments. As recently as the early 1990s, MSU was last among the eleven Big Ten schools, with barely over $100 million in endowment funds. However, in the early 2000s, the university started a campaign to increase the size of the endowment. At the close of FY 2004–05, the endowment had risen to $1.325 billion, raising the university to sixth of the 11 Big Ten schools in terms of endowment; within $2M of the fifth-rated school. The rapid increase in the size of the endowment will help to improve outdated facilities, such as the Music Building, which the College of Music hopes to soon replace with money from its alumni fundraising program.
Programs.
James Madison College.
<a href="James%20Madison%20College">James Madison College</a> (JMC), one of MSU's three <a href="residential%20college">residential college</a>s, started in 1967. The concept behind Madison College was to merge the best attributes of a small <a href="Public%20administration">public affairs</a> college with the resources of a major university. Though JMC started as an experiment, it is now a well-respected <a href="liberal%20arts">liberal arts</a> program. Madison admits about 320 students each year, holding the total student body around 1,150. Classes in the college are small, with an average of 25 students, and most instructors are <a href="tenure">tenure</a> track <a href="Faculty%20%28teaching%20staff%29">faculty</a> with PhDs or occasionally PhD candidates. As a residential college, JMC has its classrooms, offices, and student housing together in <a href="Case%20Hall">Case Hall</a>. As part of its "living-learning" philosophy, JMC requires freshmen students to live in Case during their freshman year.
Madison offers <a href="Academic%20major">majors</a>, which students choose at the end of their freshman year. The four majors are <a href="Political%20Theory">Political Theory</a> and <a href="Constitutional">Constitutional</a> <a href="Democracy">Democracy</a>, <a href="International%20relations">International Relations</a>, <a href="Social%20relation">Social Relations</a> and Policy, and Comparative <a href="Culture">Culture</a>s and Politics. All of JMC's majors require two years of foreign language and one "field experience”, either in the form of an <a href="intern">intern</a>ship or study abroad program. James Madison College also has a fairly large amount of academically successful students. Madison boasts numerous major award recipients, including Rhodes, Truman, Fulbright and Marshall Scholars to name a few. About 15% of its students are in the <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20Honors%20College">Honors College</a> and though JMC only represents about 4% of MSU graduates the college, they make up around 35% of the MSU's <a href="Phi%20Beta%20Kappa%20Society">Phi Beta Kappa</a> members.
Residential College for Arts and Humanities.
In 2007, MSU accepted its first class of students for the <a href="Residential%20College%20in%20Arts%20%26amp%3B%20Humanities">Residential College in Arts & Humanities</a>. Founded October 21, 2005, the college provides around 600 <a href="undergraduates">undergraduates</a> with an individualized <a href="curriculum">curriculum</a> in the <a href="liberal%20arts">liberal</a>, <a href="visual%20arts">visual</a> and <a href="performing%20arts">performing arts</a>. Though all the students will graduate with the same <a href="academic%20degree">degree</a>, MSU will encourage students in the college to get a <a href="Double%20degree">second degree</a> or specialization. The new college will be MSU's fourth residential college, after <a href="James%20Madison%20College">James Madison College</a>, the <a href="Lyman%20Briggs%20School">Lyman Briggs School</a>, and the now-defunct Justin Morrill College. Although early proposals named the college after <a href="Nelson%20Mandela">Nelson Mandela</a>, university officials have not decided on a permanent name , saying that it is still too early to fix a permanent name to the college.
RCAH classes will start in Autumn 2007 in the <a href="Gothic%20Revival%20architecture">Collegiate Gothic</a> Snyder-Phillips Residence Hall. Built in 1947, Snyder-Phillips once housed Justin Morrill College. MSU is currently renovating the dormitory to make room for the new college. Along with a new dining hall and upgraded bathrooms, the expanded Snyder-Phillips will include a 150-seat multipurpose classroom and <a href="performing%20arts">performing arts</a> space, a student art gallery, a <a href="Wi-Fi">Wi-Fi</a>-enabled coffeeshop, music practice rooms, and a language learning center.
Lyman Briggs College.
The <a href="Lyman%20Briggs%20College">Lyman Briggs College</a> teaches math and science within social, historical and philosophical contexts. Founded in 1967 as Lyman Briggs College, it was merged into the College of Natural Science in 1981, though the college has now regained its full college status. Many Lyman Briggs students intend to pursue careers in medicine, but the school supports 37 coordinate majors, from human biology to computer sciences. Lyman Briggs is one of the few colleges that lets undergraduates teach as "Learning Assistants."
MSU College of Law.
The <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20College%20of%20Law">Michigan State University College of Law</a> was founded in 1891. It was originally named Detroit College of Law, as it was the first law school founded in <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a>. Detroit College of Law became affiliated with Michigan State University in 1995 (changing its name to MSU College of Law), and began offering joint degree programs, including JD-MBA and various <a href="LLM">LLM</a> programs. Students attending MSU College of Law come from 42 states and 13 countries, with applications tripling since affiliating with MSU in 1995. Full-time and part-time (night) students can participate in 8 concentrations, including the Trial Practice Institute. The law school publishes the "<a href="Michigan%20State%20Law%20Review">Michigan State Law Review</a>" and several other journals.
The first trial practice institute in the United States, the Geoffrey Fieger Trial Practice Institute, started at Michigan State University College of Law with a grant of $4 million from <a href="Geoffrey%20Fieger">Geoffrey Fieger</a>. The <a href="Intellectual%20Property">Intellectual Property</a> and Communications Law program is ranked number 1 among law schools in the <a href="Big%20Ten%20Conference">Big Ten Conference</a>, and number 17 in the United States. In addition, MSU College of Law's Indigenous Law Program offers an Indigenous Law Certificate Program.
Eli Broad College of Business.
The <a href="Eli%20Broad%20College%20of%20Business">Eli Broad College of Business</a> has programs in <a href="accounting">accounting</a>, <a href="information%20systems">information systems</a>, <a href="finance">finance</a>, <a href="The%20School%20of%20Hospitality%20Business">hospitality business</a>, <a href="human%20resources%20management">human resources management</a>, <a href="management">management</a>, <a href="marketing">marketing</a>, and <a href="supply%20chain%20management">supply chain management</a>. Undergraduate students must apply to the college and be admitted as juniors. The college has 2,066 admitted <a href="undergraduate">undergraduate</a> students and 817 <a href="graduate%20students">graduate students</a>.
"The" School of Hospitality Business is an industry-specific school within the business college with separate admission statistics. It started with 18 students and now has 402 admitted <a href="undergraduate">undergraduate</a> students, 34 <a href="graduate%20student">graduate student</a>s, and 13 full-time <a href="Faculty%20%28teaching%20staff%29">faculty</a> members.
The Eli Broad Graduate School of Management, which "<a href="Forbes">Forbes</a>" magazine ranks 19th in the U.S., offers 3 <a href="MBA">MBA</a> programs, as well as <a href="double%20major">joint degrees</a> with the <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20College%20of%20Law">College of Law</a>. Other master's programs include accounting, business analytics, finance, food service business management, hospitality business management, marketing research, and supply chain management.
The college has been accredited by the <a href="AACSB">Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business (AACSB)</a> since 1953.
Honors College.
The Honors College was established in 1956 to provide more academic opportunities to MSU students, and to emphasize academic challenge and achievement. It is currently housed in <a href="Eustace-Cole%20Hall">Eustace-Cole Hall</a> on the northern portion of <a href="Campus%20of%20Michigan%20State%20University">MSU's campus</a>.
Members of the Honors College at Michigan State University enjoy a great deal of freedom over their academic planning. They are allowed to skip prerequisites, substitute departmental courses for general education requirements, and enroll in Honors courses. Honors College members are also eligible to enroll in <a href="postgraduate%20education">graduate courses</a>. Upon graduation from the Honors College, a student receives an Honors College <a href="academic%20stole">stole</a> to wear at <a href="Graduation">commencement</a>.
Human Medicine.
MSU opened the College of Human Medicine was founded in 1964. The main pre-clinical campus is located on Michigan State University's main campus in East Lansing, while half of the class studies at the Secchia Center in Grand Rapids. Clinical practice, undergraduate medical education during the clinical years three and four, graduate medical education, and research takes place across six campuses located in the Michigan cities of <a href="Flint%2C%20Michigan">Flint</a>, <a href="Grand%20Rapids">Grand Rapids</a>, <a href="Lansing">Lansing</a>, Traverse City, Midland, and <a href="Marquette%2C%20Michigan">Marquette</a>.
Osteopathic Medicine.
Michigan State University College of Osteopathic Medicine was founded in 1969 as the first osteopathic medical school on a public university campus. The main pre-clinical campus is located in <a href="East%20Lansing">East Lansing</a>, with two additional sites in <a href="Macomb%20Township%2C%20Michigan">Macomb</a> and <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a>. Clerkship medical education takes place throughout Michigan in one of the many Statewide Campus System hospitals. Basic and clinical research takes places at all sites.
Resources.
Libraries.
The <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20Libraries">Michigan State University Library</a> is the 26th largest academic <a href="library">library</a> system in North America with over 4.7 million volumes and 6.4 million <a href="microform">microform</a>s. The university library comprises nine branch locations including the main library. The <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20Libraries%23Africana">Africana Collection</a> is one of the largest of its kind in the nation with a collection of over 200,000 items. Other significant collections include <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20Libraries%23Vincent%20Voice%20Library%20Collection">The G. Robert Vincent Voice Library</a>, the largest academic voice library in the nation, containing a collection of over 40,000 hours of <a href="audiobook">spoken word recordings</a> and includes the voices of over 100,000 persons from all walks of life, and the <a href="Michigan%20State%20University%20Libraries%23Comic%20Art%20Collection">Russel B. Nye Popular Culture Collections</a> which includes the extensive <a href="Comic%20book">Comic Art</a> Collection. This collection currently includes over 100,000 <a href="comic%20books">comic books</a>, and 10,000 related books and periodicals.
Press.
Michigan State University Press is the publishing arm of Michigan State University. It traces its origins to the late 1940s when the Michigan State Board of Agriculture established a publishing program at Michigan State College (MSC). President <a href="John%20A.%20Hannah">John A. Hannah</a> made a recommendation on publications to a special committee. In response, the committee members recommended to Hannah that Michigan State College Press be created. The president acted on their advice and on July 1, 1947, the publishing house came into being. In addition to its own publishing program, Michigan State University Press distributes books from The African Books Collective, a consortium of more than 110 African small and scholarly publishers headquartered in Oxford, England. They also publish books for four <a href="Canada">Canadian</a> publishers, as wells as books from the National Museum of Science and Industry, London.
